qaPairs.question: Who is the instructor for this class?
qaPairs.answer: Your instructor is Dr. Keola Donaghy. You may address him as simply 'Keola' or 'Kumu' if you prefer.

qaPairs.question: What is the instructor's email?
alternateQuestions: How do I email the instructor?
qaPairs.answer: Dr. Donaghy's email is donaghy@hawaii.edu. He prefers communication to be initiated by email.

qaPairs.question: Where is the instructor's office?
alternateQuestions: Where can I find the instructor?
qaPairs.answer: Dr. Donaghy's office is in Ka'a'ike 113.

qaPairs.question: What are the instructor's office hours?
alternateQuestions: When can I meet with the professor?
How do I schedule time with the instructor?
qaPairs.answer: Office hours are by appointment. Contact Dr. Donaghy at donaghy@hawaii.edu to schedule a meeting.

qaPairs.question: What is the instructor's phone number?
alternateQuestions: How do I call the instructor?
qaPairs.answer: Dr. Donaghy's phone number is 808-984-3570.

qaPairs.question: Can I meet with the instructor on Zoom?
alternateQuestions: Does the instructor do video calls?
Can we have a virtual meeting?
qaPairs.answer: Yes, Zoom meetings are available by request. Contact Dr. Donaghy by email to request a Zoom meeting.

qaPairs.question: What is the full name of this course?
qaPairs.answer: This is MUS/HWST 176: The History of Hawaiian Music. It doesn't matter which of these two classes you registered for - the content and requirements are the same.

qaPairs.question: When does the semester run?
alternateQuestions: When does class start and end?
qaPairs.answer: The semester runs from August 25, 2025 to December 19, 2025.

qaPairs.question: When does the class meet?
alternateQuestions: Do we have to be online at specific times?
qaPairs.answer: This class is conducted completely online and asynchronously. You are not required to be logged in at any particular time to complete assignments or tests.

qaPairs.question: What textbook do I need?
alternateQuestions: Do I need to buy a textbook?
qaPairs.answer: No textbook is required. Your instructor will provide you with all necessary reading materials.

qaPairs.question: What technology do I need for this class?
qaPairs.answer: You need: a recent computer, reliable high-speed Internet connection, speakers or headphones for high-quality audio, supported browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge), Adobe Reader, and digital storage.

qaPairs.question: Where do I access course materials?
alternateQuestions: How do I get to the course website?
qaPairs.answer: All readings, activities, assignments, and quizzes are found on Lamakū at https://lamaku.hawaii.edu/d2l/login.

qaPairs.question: How is the course structured?
qaPairs.answer: There are 16 modules, each completed over one week. Each module opens on Tuesday at noon, and all assignments and quizzes must be completed by the following Tuesday at 11:59 PM.

qaPairs.question: When are assignments due?
qaPairs.answer: I do not have information on specific due dates for quizzes, discussion board posts, paper submissions and other such deadlines. Please check your class website and calendar for detailed information on deadlines. But generally speaking, all assignments and quizzes are due every Tuesday at 11:59 PM. Each week follows this same schedule.

qaPairs.question: What's the late assignment policy?
alternateQuestions: Can I turn in late work?
What happens if I miss a deadline?
Can I submit work after the deadline?
qaPairs.answer: Late assignments are NOT accepted except under unusual circumstances, with advance notice and approval from your instructor, or in case of documentable hardship or emergency.

qaPairs.question: What happens if I don't complete first week assignments?
alternateQuestions: Can I be dropped from the class?
qaPairs.answer: First week assignments are both mandatory and critical. If you fail to complete them or email for an extension before the deadline, you will be dropped from the class. If dropped, you must explain why and get instructor approval, then email the registrar's office (uhmctc@hawaii.edu) to be added back.

qaPairs.question: How are grades calculated?
qaPairs.answer: Grades are weighted as follows: Quizzes = 30%, Assignments/Forum Discussions = 15%, Midterm Exam = 25%, Final Research Proposal/Draft/Submission = 30%.

qaPairs.question: What's the grading scale?
alternateQuestions: What percentage do I need for an A?
qaPairs.answer: The grading scale is: A (90-100%), B (80-89%), C (70-79%), D (60-69%), F (0-59%). No pluses or minuses are used in the UH Community College system.

qaPairs.question: What's the final research project?
alternateQuestions: Do we have a final paper?
qaPairs.answer: There are three options: 1) Write a report on a Hawaiian music performance you attend this semester, 2) Interview a Hawaiian music performer, or 3) Undertake a special research project with instructor approval. The paper must be 5 pages, 12-point Times New Roman, double-spaced, with at least 2 sources (one academic).

qaPairs.question: When are research paper components due?
alternateQuestions: When do I submit my research project?
qaPairs.answer: Research paper deadlines: Proposals due Tuesday, Oct 22, 2024 at 11:59 PM; Drafts due Tuesday, Nov 19, 2024 at 11:59 PM; Final Papers due Tuesday, Dec 10, 2024 at 11:59 PM.

qaPairs.question: Is there a midterm exam?
qaPairs.answer: Yes, there is a midterm exam that includes all material covered up to that point. The midterm is scheduled for Week 9 (Pule 9). There is no final exam.

qaPairs.question: What topics will we cover?
alternateQuestions: What will I learn in this class?
qaPairs.answer: Weekly topics include: Introduction, Instruments/Terminology/Ethnomusicology, Oli (Chant Forms), Older Hula Forms, Older Hawaiian Instruments, Later Hula Forms and Mele Hawai'i, Hīmeni (Hymns), Nā Lani 'Ehā (The Four Royals), 'Ukulele, Slack Key Guitar, Steel Guitar, Hapa-Haole, Hawaiian Renaissance, and Hawaiian Music Activism.

qaPairs.question: Can I use AI for assignments?
alternateQuestions: What about ChatGPT or other AI tools?
qaPairs.answer: AI-generated submissions are not permitted and will be treated as plagiarism. You may use AI to locate research resources, but beware of inaccurate information about Hawaiian music. Don't trust AI - verify everything it tells you. AI-based recording tools (Otter.ai, etc.) are not permitted for class conversations.

qaPairs.question: Is attendance required?
alternateQuestions: Do I have to attend class?
qaPairs.answer: As the class is completely online, attendance is not taken. However, you must log in weekly to complete assignments. You should check email and Lamakū at least once daily for updates.

qaPairs.question: What are the prerequisites for this class?
alternateQuestions: Do I need any previous courses?
Can I take this without prerequisites?
qaPairs.answer: While the course catalog lists several prerequisites, the instructor will happily waive them for anyone. Contact Dr. Donaghy if you're interested in taking the class.

qaPairs.question: Where can I get academic help?
qaPairs.answer: Visit The Learning Center for tutoring and academic support. Links: Tutoring (http://maui.hawaii.edu/kakoo/tutoring), Learning Resources (https://maui.hawaii.edu/tlc/home/learning-resources/).

qaPairs.question: How do I get disability accommodations?
qaPairs.answer: Contact the Disability Services Counselor at 984-3227, UHMCDS@hawaii.edu, or Room C-03 in the Learning Center. Students should reach out well before the semester begins. Visit https://maui.hawaii.edu/disability/.

qaPairs.question: Who do I contact for technical problems?
qaPairs.answer: For technical support: UH ITS Help Desk - email help@hawaii.edu or call 956-8883 (1-800-558-2669 from neighbor islands). Support is available 24/7 including holidays.

qaPairs.question: Where can I get financial aid help?
alternateQuestions: I need help paying for school
qaPairs.answer: Contact Financial Aid at http://maui.hawaii.edu/financial/ for assistance with funding your education.

qaPairs.question: Do I need to use Hawaiian language marks?
alternateQuestions: How do I type Hawaiian words correctly?
qaPairs.answer: Correct diacritical marks (ʻokina and kahakō) are expected. Use the online Hawaiian dictionary at wehewehe.org. Hawaiian keyboards are available for Mac, Windows, iOS, Android, and Chrome OS.

qaPairs.question: How will the instructor communicate with students?
alternateQuestions: How do I get class updates?
How does the professor contact us?
qaPairs.answer: Dr. Donaghy uses Lamakū's 'Announcements' function and will communicate at least weekly about deadlines and assignments. You cannot reply directly to these emails - change the recipient to donaghy@hawaii.edu if you want to respond.

qaPairs.question: Are there discussion forums?
qaPairs.answer: Yes, early in the semester you'll use the Lamakū 'Forum' function to express thoughts on topics and questions. Students should engage respectfully and address issues rather than targeting classmates.

qaPairs.question: What are the rules for online behavior?
qaPairs.answer: Follow proper netiquette rules. Visit 'Aloha - Online Netiquette' guidelines and '15 Rules of Netiquette for Online Discussion Boards.' Be respectful in all online interactions and follow UHMC's Student Code of Conduct.

qaPairs.question: What citation format should I use?
qaPairs.answer: Use APA format for all citations and bibliography. Visit the library resource 'Cite Your Source!' at http://maui.hawaii.libguides.com/cite for more information.

qaPairs.question: How do I submit drafts and final papers?
alternateQuestions: Where do I turn in papers?
How do I share my paper?
qaPairs.answer: Drafts and final papers must be submitted via Google Docs by sending the instructor a link. Proposals are submitted through Lamakū, not by email.

qaPairs.question: Is extra credit available?
alternateQuestions: Can I do extra work for points?
qaPairs.answer: Dr. Donaghy does not offer extra credit for students who have not completed required assignments. There is an optional extra credit project to create a traditional Hawaiian musical instrument using a printed reference.

qaPairs.question: When is the final exam?
qaPairs.answer: There is no final exam. The last day of instruction is December 11, 2025. The final evaluation period is December 13-20, 2025.

qaPairs.question: How much time should I spend on this class?
qaPairs.answer: You should commit to working 12-15 hours per week for activities and assignments. This includes completing all readings, discussions, and quizzes.

qaPairs.question: Should I form a study group?
alternateQuestions: Can I work with other students?
qaPairs.answer: Yes, you should form a 2-3 person study team and exchange contact information within the first two weeks. This helps with course success.

qaPairs.question: How can the library help me?
alternateQuestions: Where do I get research help?
qaPairs.answer: The library offers multiple services: Borrow Technology (https://maui.hawaii.libguides.com/equipment), Library & Research Help (https://maui.hawaii.edu/library/), and research assistance for your papers.

qaPairs.question: Can I print or borrow technology on campus?
qaPairs.answer: Yes! Visit these links: Printing (https://maui.hawaii.libguides.com/print), Borrow Technology (https://maui.hawaii.libguides.com/equipment), and UHMC IT Help (https://maui.hawaii.edu/helpdesk/).

qaPairs.question: Where can I study on campus?
alternateQuestions: Can I book a study space?
qaPairs.answer: You can book study spaces at https://maui-hawaii.libcal.com/allspaces. Check the Student Support Statement webpage for more information about places to study on campus.

qaPairs.question: When are the add/drop deadlines?
alternateQuestions: Can I still add this class?
qaPairs.answer: View the complete Academic Calendar for Fall 2025 Tuition Refund and Withdrawal Deadlines at https://maui.hawaii.edu/academic-deadlines.

qaPairs.question: What student activities are available?
qaPairs.answer: Visit Student Life at https://maui.hawaii.edu/studentlife/ for information about campus activities, organizations, and student life opportunities.

qaPairs.question: Who do I contact about discrimination or harassment?
alternateQuestions: Where do I report Title IX issues?
I need to report inappropriate behavior
qaPairs.answer: Contact Title IX at http://maui.hawaii.edu/title-ix/ for issues related to discrimination, harassment, or sexual misconduct.

qaPairs.question: Who do I contact for security issues?
qaPairs.answer: Contact Security at http://maui.hawaii.edu/security/ for campus safety and security concerns.

qaPairs.question: Is there a testing center?
alternateQuestions: Do you have a quiet testing space?
qaPairs.answer: Yes, visit the Testing Center at https://maui.hawaii.edu/testing/?s=testing+center for information about testing services and quiet exam spaces.

qaPairs.question: How do I access my student records?
alternateQuestions: Where do I see my grades?
How do I register for classes?
qaPairs.answer: Use My UH (https://myuh.hawaii.edu/) for student services and STAR Services (https://www.star.hawaii.edu/studentinterface/) for registration and academic records.

qaPairs.question: Are there services for neighbor island students?
alternateQuestions: I live on Molokaʻi, is there help?
qaPairs.answer: If you live in Molokaʻi, Lānaʻi, or Hana, visit the UHMC Outreach Centers webpage at http://maui.hawaii.edu/outreach-centers/ for local support and services.

qaPairs.question: Is there a UHMC mobile app?
alternateQuestions: Can I get UHMC on my phone?
qaPairs.answer: Yes! Download the UHMC App from the Apple App Store or Google Play. The app provides easy access to campus information and services.

qaPairs.question: How can I follow UHMC on social media?
alternateQuestions: What social media does the college have?
qaPairs.answer: Follow UHMC on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/UHMauiCollege), Instagram (@uhmaui), and Twitter (@uhmaui) for updates and campus news.

qaPairs.question: Can I use Wikipedia as a source?
qaPairs.answer: No, you may not use Wikipedia as a reference for research papers. You also may not cite lecture notes or lectures. However, you may use Wikipedia to locate other legitimate sources.

qaPairs.question: Can I interview someone for my research project?
alternateQuestions: What if I want to interview a Hawaiian musician?
Is interviewing allowed for the paper?
qaPairs.answer: Yes! One research option is to interview a performer of Hawaiian music. Include research about the individual, their performance style, how they learned Hawaiian music, and other relevant cultural information.

qaPairs.question: Can I attend a performance for my research project?
alternateQuestions: What if I go to a Hawaiian music concert?
Can I write about a live performance?
qaPairs.answer: Yes! You can write a report on a Hawaiian music performance that you attend THIS SEMESTER (not something from the past). Include research and background information on the performance style and cultural elements.

qaPairs.question: Can the syllabus change during the semester?
qaPairs.answer: This syllabus and certain details are subject to change. While major components (curriculum, quizzes, assignments, final project) likely won't change, the instructor reserves the right to modify schedules and assignments as circumstances dictate.

qaPairs.question: What is the title of Dr. Donaghy's book?
alternateQuestions: Did Dr. Donaghy write a book?
What book did the instructor publish?
Has Dr. Donaghy written books before?
qaPairs.answer: Dr. Donaghy's book is titled 'Mele On The Mauna: Perpetuating Genealogies of Hawaiian Musical Activism,' published by Indiana University Press. It discusses the role music played in the struggle to defend Maunakea. This is his first book, so he has not written any books previously.

qaPairs.question: How many Nā Hōkū Hanohano Awards does Dr. Donaghy have?
alternateQuestions: What awards has Dr. Donaghy won?
Has the instructor won music awards?
qaPairs.answer: Dr. Donaghy has been honored with eight Nā Hōkū Hanohano Awards as a composer, producer, and performer of Hawaiian music. Four were for CDs he produced for the Institute of Hawaiian Music program, two with his group A'ea'e, one with the rock group 'Sandemonium,' and one for co-producing Kenneth Makuakāne's recent anthology release.

qaPairs.question: Where did Dr. Donaghy grow up on Maui?
alternateQuestions: Where is the instructor from on Maui?
Where did Dr. Donaghy spend his childhood?
qaPairs.answer: Dr. Donaghy grew up in Kama'ole on Maui and attended the old Kīhei Elementary School (now the Kīhei Youth Center) and St. Anthony High School. He spent two years at Maui Community College before moving to Hilo in 1994.

qaPairs.question: Is Dr. Donaghy married?
alternateQuestions: Does the instructor have a family?
Tell me about Dr. Donaghy's family
qaPairs.answer: Yes, Dr. Donaghy and his wife live in Wailuku. They have a son who lives in Puna on Hawai'i island with his wife and their granddaughter and grandson, and their daughter and another grandson live in Wailuku.

qaPairs.question: Tell me about Dr. Donaghy's work in technology?
alternateQuestions: What technology work has Dr. Donaghy done?
How is the instructor involved with music technology?
qaPairs.answer: Dr. Donaghy's work in technological empowerment spans decades, focusing on Hawaiian and Pacific Languages. He worked for Steely Dan's Walter Becker configuring digital music technologies, was featured in Wired Magazine in 1995 for developing Leokī (a pioneering Hawaiian-language intranet), and helped design UHMC's recording studio. His contributions ensure Hawaiian language users can meaningfully use digital devices and online environments.
